{"messages":[{"role":"user","content":"<|context|><|s1|><DOCUMENT 2: Map 2 - European countries (EU-27, Iceland and Switzerland) that refer to justice considerations in their national reporting under the Governance Regulation of the Energy Union and Climate Action (Article 17 and 19) - 2023 | 2.7 Climate risks to society | Europe's environment 2025 (EEA)
><end||s><|s2|><Source: Website
><end||s><|s3|><The map shows which countries mention justice directly, indirectly or not at all, in their reporting under the Governance Regulation, 2023 reporting cycle.
><end||s><|s4|><Data are based on information from country reports submitted under Articles 17 and 19 of the EU Governance Regulation from 2023.

DOCUMENT 6: Overview of adaptation policies in Europe | 2.9 Governance of climate change mitigation and adaptation | Europe's environment 2025 (EEA)
><end||s><|s44|><Source: Website
><end||s><|s45|><The figure provides an overview of climate adaptation policies in Europe, drawing on data from official EU reporting (20152025) and internal mapping of national climate laws. ><end||s><|s46|><It is based on reports under the Monitoring Mechanism Regulation and the Governance Regulation, and is complemented by analysis from the EEA and ETC CA published in their 2024 report.
><end||s><|s47|><---

><end||s><|s48|><Source: Website
><end||s><|s49|><The figure shows the availability of public funding at each stage of the innovation process.

DOCUMENT 19: Total greenhouse gas emissions (without LULUCF) | Denmark | Europe's environment 2025 (EEA)
><end||s><|s91|><Source: Website
><end||s><|s92|><The indicator shows the trend in total greenhouse gas emissions, excluding those from the land use, land use change and forestry (LULUCF) sector. ><end||s><|s93|><For comparison, two index lines (1990 value = 100) are included: the first refers to country specific emissions, while the second expresses total EU emissions.
><end||s><|s94|><Not assessed
><end||s><|s95|>< 
Assessment
><end||s><|s96|><Data sources
><end||s><|s97|><Metadata
><end||s><|s98|><Denmarks green transition has accelerated since 1990.><end||s><|s99|><The 2025 Danish climate inventory and projection estimates that total emissions in Denmark for 2023 amounted to 38.8 Mt of carbon dioxide equivalent (CO 2 eq), corresponding to a reduction of approximately 51.0% in 2023 compared with 1990; when excluding the land use, land use change and forestry (LULUCF) sector, this figure becomes 39.3 Mt CO 2 eq, corresponding to a 45.8% reduction compared with 1990. ><end||s><|s100|><Thus, Denmark achieved its interim target of a 5055% reduction by 2025 two years in advance. ><end||s><|s101|><In 2030, Danish total net emissions are estimated to amount to 22.2 Mt CO 2 eq, corresponding to a reduction of approximately 72% compared with 1990 . ><end||s><|s102|><Therefore, Denmark is on track to meet the national climate target of a 70% reduction in total emissions by 2030, compared with 1990 levels.
><end||s><|s103|><To achieve its climate goals, Denmark has introduced a high and uniform carbon dioxide tax on industry . ><end||s><|s104|><Building on this foundation, the green tripartite agreement agrees to implement the worlds first CO 2 eq tax on agriculture. ><end||s><|s105|><Furthermore, EU obligations related to the LULUCF Regulation are expected to be met, and the measures contribute to further overachievement in terms of the burden-sharing agreement.
><end||s><|s106|><- Total GHG emissions and removals in the EU , EEA
><end||s><|s107|><Topics
Climate change mitigation
><end||s><|s108|><Forests and forestry
><end||s><|s109|><Land use Geographical coverage
><end||s><|s110|><- Denmark Temporal coverage
><end||s><|s111|><1990-2023
><end||s><|s112|><Related content
><end||s><|s113|><References and footnotes
><end||s><|s114|><- Ministry of Climate, Energy and Utilities, Klimastatus og -fremskrivning 2025, Copenhagen, 2025, accessed 1 July 2025, https://www.kefm.dk/Media/638816066524560592/KEFM_KF25_DEL1_300425_.pdf .
><end||s><|s115|><---
DOCUMENT 22: EU progress under the HFC phase-down set out in the F-gas Regulation | 2.5 Ozone-depleting substances and fluorinated greenhouse gases | Europe's environment 2025 (EEA)
><end||s><|s116|><Source: Website
><end||s><|s117|><This graph shows the progress of the hydrofluorocarbon (HFC) phase-down under EU F-gas Regulation.
><end||s><|s118|><* HFC: hydrofluorocarbon
><end||s><|s119|><* POM: placing on the market
><end||s><|s120|><* RACHP: refrigeration, air conditioning and heat pump
><end||s><|s121|><Data shown for 2023 are preliminary and subject to further validation by the European Commission. ><end||s><|s122|><The maximum quantities of the EU HFC phase-down shown for 2015-2019 apply to EU-28, for 2020 to EU-27+UK. ><end||s><|s123|><EU-27 maximum quantities for 2021 onwards have been recalculated to reflect the effects of Brexit.
><end||s><|s124|>< 
This visualization was originally used in:
><end||s><|s125|><- EEA, 2024, Hydrofluorocarbon phase-down in Europe ( https://www.eea.europa.eu/en/analysis/indicators/hydrofluorocarbon-phase-down-in-europe ) accessed 21 January 2025.
><end||s><|s126|><Assessment

DOCUMENT 29: Sectorial greenhouse gas emission reduction progress towards 2030 | Europe’s environment and climate: knowledge for resilience, prosperity and sustainability | Europe's environment 2025 (EEA)
><end||s><|s169|><Source: Website
><end||s><|s170|><This figure presents the GHG emissions per sector in the EU for 2005 and 2023, and model based outcomes that reflect required ambition level for 2030. ><end||s><|s171|><The reference model based emissions levels for 2030 are based on the mix 55 scenario, one of the core policy scenarios underpinning the 2030 climate target plan.

DOCUMENT 31: EU Greenhouse Gas Emissions: Sectorial progress towards 2030 | 2.1 Greenhouse gas emissions | Europe's environment 2025 (EEA)
><end||s><|s210|><Source: Website
><end||s><|s211|><This figure presents the GHG emissions per sector in the EU for 2005 and 2023, and model based outcomes that reflect required ambition level for 2030. ><end||s><|s212|><The emission data for 2005 and 2023 are from EEA (2025),while the reference model based emisisons levels for 2030 are based on the mix 55 scenario, one of the core policy scenaroi#s underpinning the 2030 climate target plan.
><end||s><|s213|>< 
The model-based emissions in the MIX 55 scenario refer to a core policy scenario underpinning the 2030 Climate Target Plan ( 4 ) , while the emission data are from the EEA ( 3 ) .
><end||s><|s214|><The sources for this note can be found in the chart sources
><end||s><|s215|><Assessment

><end||s><|s252|><References and footnotes><end||s><end||context><|request|><Make one or more claims about information in the documents.><end||request><|response|><|r1|><**EU actions to combat climate change**
><end||r><|r2|><
| EU Action area | Key measures / initiatives | Reference |
><end||r><|r3|><|----------------|---------------------------|-----------|
><end||r><|r4|><| Governance & reporting | Governance Regulation (Articles 17 & 19) requires Member States to report on climate mitigation, adaptation and justice (direct/indirect mentions). | [[2]](https://www.eea.europa.eu/en/europe-environment-2025/thematic-briefings/climate-change/climate-risks-to-society/european-countries-eu-27-iceland-and-switzerland) |
><end||r><|r5|><| Emissions‑reduction targets | 70 % cut in total GHG emissions by 2030 (vs 1990) under the “Fit for 55” package; sector‑specific pathways modelled in the MIX‑55 scenario. | [[29]](https://www.eea.europa.eu/en/europe-environment-2025/main-report/eu-greenhouse-gas-emissions), [[31]](https://www.eea.europa.eu/en/europe-environment-2025/thematic-briefings/climate-change/greenhouse-gas-emissions/eu-greenhouse-gas-emissions-sectorial-progress-towards-2030) |
><end||r><|r6|><| HFC phase‑down | EU F‑gas Regulation imposes a step‑wise reduction of hydrofluorocarbons; progress shown for 2015‑2023. | [[22]](https://www.eea.europa.eu/en/europe-environment-2025/thematic-briefings/climate-change/ozone-depleting-substances-and-fluorinated-greenhouse-gases/eu-progress-under-the-hydrofluorocarbon-1) |
><end||r><|r7|><| Public funding for climate‑related technologies | € billions of public funding allocated across innovation phases (research, demonstration, market uptake) for 2021‑2027. | [[16]](https://www.eea.europa.eu/en/europe-environment-2025/main-report/available-public-funding-for-climate) |
><end||r><|r8|><| Adaptation policies | EU monitors and supports national climate‑adaptation policies (2015‑2025) and maps national climate laws. | [[6]](https://www.eea.europa.eu/en/europe-environment-2025/thematic-briefings/climate-change/governance-of-climate-change-mitigation-and-adaptation/overview-of-climate-governance-in-the-eu) |
><end||r><|r9|><| LULUCF obligations | Member States must comply with the EU LULUCF Regulation to ensure forest and land‑use sinks contribute to climate targets. | [[19]](https://www.eea.europa.eu/en/europe-environment-2025/countries/denmark/total-greenhouse-gas-emissions) |
><end||r><|r10|><| Sector‑specific progress | Emissions from energy, transport, agriculture and other sectors are tracked; modelled 2030 pathways guide required ambition. | [[29]](https://www.eea.europa.eu/en/europe-environment-2025/main-report/eu-greenhouse-gas-emissions), [[31]](https://www.eea.europa.eu/en/europe-environment-2025/thematic-briefings/climate-change/greenhouse-gas-emissions/eu-greenhouse-gas-emissions-sectorial-progress-towards-2030) |
><end||r><|r11|><
*All information is drawn from the Europe’s environment 2025 data set.><end||r><end||response>"}],"temperature":0,"model":"Inhouse-LLM/HallOumi-8B","logprobs":true,"top_logprobs":3}
